text: Bottle @ Fox and hounds, Sønderborg. Dark brown almost black with a big, creamy beige head. Relatively light aroma for this kind of beer, dark malt, light caramel, some vanilla and hint of wood. Flavor is medium sweet, dark malt, caramel, some peat and moderate bitterness. Medium body and shorter aftertaste than expected. Quite nice and probably one of the better one from Innis & Gunn and luckily no butterscotch here as this almost seems to be the signature flavor. Still a bit disappointing as the package and price indicates something of extraordinary high quality.

Bottle from hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. Quite dark and with some amber highlights. A big tan head that falls slowly. Aroma is wood with toffee and vanilla. The flavor is very close to that. Buttery toffee and vanilla outshine the wood. There is earth and gentle wood notes. Its not a complicated beer.

This was a joint tasting with Strykzone. This one has aged some. Pours brown color with a large, very foamy, long lasting, beige head with great retention that has good lacing. Nose of sweet caramel malt, toffee, vanilla, and quite a bit of oak. The body is on the thin side and the mouthfeel is soft with lots of carbonation. Flavor has bourbon and oak, along with vanilla and fruit, Finish is chocolate and bourbon on oak. Overall quite good.

Tonight I cracked a limited Oak-aged Innis & Gunn ale expression.

Sleeping for over 3 months in first-filled bourbon barrels, there is no surprise we have some significant cask character. 

Formerly I found I&G beers to be a one trick pony with very limited malt character and almost completely a cask finish palette. 

Not so here my friends. Instant caramel, toffee, butterscotch and rich mineral groundwater here. The cask character is a pronounced one with all the sweet vanilla and oak notes you would expect. The deep palette is complex, very satisfying, and finishes exceptionally smooth.

Draught at En ÖL och Whiskeymässa cons 2017-03-26 Göteborg, Should be called "vintage 2015 - 100 days".
AR: caramel fudge, wee peaty
AP: dark brown, cream brown head
F: caramel fudge, sweet mouth feeling

500ml bottle. (2015 vintage) Pours a hazy red-brown with a large, creamy, long lasting, beige head that laces. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, toffee, oak and vanilla. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, dark fruit, orange, molasses, vanilla and oak with just a hint of bourbon in a dry, mildly bitter, herbal finish. Medium body with a creamy, smooth, oily texture and soft carbonation. Nice, one of their better beers.

Bottle. 2015 vintage. Pours a dark ruby-brown body with a very large tan head that takes a while to recede. Aroma has a nice complexity, with notes of vanilla, caramel, dried dark fruit (dates, figs), oxidized apple, oak, anise and leather. Flavour is simpler, but still very good, with nice vanilla toffee sweetness to start, oak and bourbon building in the middle, and bourbon lingering in the warm but not overly boozy finish. Hops arent especially present, but add a hint of orange oil in the finish. The medium-full body has a nice creaminess, and lacks the sticky character of some other I&G beers. A really nice beer all around, glad to have tried it.

500 ml bottle (2015 vintage), Release No. 01/16-001, best by date of 16 DEC 20 stamped on the bottle. Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours a clear very dark reddish/brown color with a huge, huge head. Had to let this one settle down a little while before I could get a decent pour in the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty, the brew smells like vanilla, toffee, toasted malt, nuts, and some dark fruit. Taste is similar to the aroma, but with the addition of some bourbon, molasses and dark breadiness. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its slick and has a high amount of soft carbonation. A little too much carbonation for me, but with that being said its not hard to drink at all. I thought it was an enjoyable brew, but maybe I should have drank it fresher. Still worth a try! $7.99 a bottle.

Bottle. Consumed 2016, bottled 2015. Pours dark brown with a thick tan foam subsiding slow and residing. Scent is resin, honey, smoke, whiskey. Taste is a blissfully smooth vanilla laced scotch ale strong, biting notes of cinnamon, cocoa, vanilla, and bourbon. Hints of peated/medicinal notes. Finish is sharp and dry but still manages to be smooth due to its ethanol. Very great beer.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel woody aroma. Fruity malty spicy caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel finish.

Aroma: peated, pears, wet wood, barrel, vanilla.
Appearance: dark amber color and creamy head.
Taste: vanilla, peated, barrel notes, dried fruits, pears, roasted dark malts, semi-dry.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, fruity finish.
Overall: Decent, but this is a kind of disappointment. Somehow flat.
Sample at DØE 2016. hazy dark amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel, hops, fruit, oak, chocolate and vanilla.

Aroma: Medium-light oak, vanilla. Light plums, vinuous, leather, berry.
Appearance: Brilliant, dark copper body. Very large, light-brown head. Rocky, good retention.
Flavour: Medium-high licorice, leather. Medium-light oak. Slight malty sweetness, almost toffee-like. Light vanilla, bourbon, alcohol. Medium bitterness. Dry finish with lingering light oak, vanilla, tobacco.
Mouthfeel: medium-high carbonation, creamy Light body. Light warming.
Overall: Complex, malty, with a good balancing bitterness. Body is a bit low and carbonation too high, but otherwise a very good beer!

500 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Dimeon
(bottle) clear dark amber colour with a very tall brown head; aroma of stewed fruit, jam, bit of wood, toffee; smooth palate; balanced flavour with a long light bitter finish

2015 vintage. Dark brown pour, with an off white almost beige head. Aroma is sweet malts, brown sugar, and earthy barrel. Hints of roasty, and nuttiness, with some light vanilla. Carb is over the top and actually a little tough to drink. Finish is very woody, and earthy, with some more sweet malts. This seems to have alot less of their trademark buttery flavour, this is quite a bit cleaner. Low to medium bitterness, decent stuff.
DØE. Vintage 2015. Hazy dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, chocolate and light wood. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 190516

500 ml bottle. Caramel and vanilla aroma. Pours black in colour with a large and frothy yellowish head. Very complex with caramel, dark fruit and vanilla flavours with some underlying notes of wood. Creamy and full bodied. Long sweet malt finish. Very good - but pricey.

Sample @ [ DOE - Olfestival Kobenhavn 2016 (Beerfestival Copenhagen) ] @ Lokomotivvaerkstedet, Otto Busses Vej 5A, 2450 Copenhagen SV, Denmark. [ As Innis & Gunn Vintage ]. [ Vintage 2015 ]. Clear medium to dark brown - red amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, wood, toffee, vanilla. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, toffee, vanilla, wood. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160519]
Bottle shared with northropfrye. This is the darkest Innis and Gunn Ive seen. Sweet and roasty aroma. A little bit smooth and subtle and the same time strong. Sweet.

Dark black body, brown head, soapy lacing, a gusher so watch out. Malty sweet aroma, brown sugar. Taste is brown sugar, molasses, dried fruit, vanilla, and a hint of anise. Not bad, but not worth $20.
Bottle, 2015 version, at KØ16. Clear dark brown colour. The flavour is citric and caramelly with a hint of vanille. Citric finish as well. Too carbonated for me.

50 cl bottle. Pours clear and golden amber to brown with a small to fully gone tan head. Aroma is wooden and caramelish. High carbonation. Dry, toasted and dark malty. Bitter and slight herbal. Dry and bitter finish.

500ml bottle pours a deep amber brown color with a 2 finger beige head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma is dark fruits, caramel and vanilla with some notes of oak. Taste is a caramel malty sweetness with hints of vanilla and a light grassy, herbal hop bitterness. Very little, if any, bourbon comes through in this brew. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Overall, a decent brew that suits the style well, but lacking a bit in flavours. Very subtle and easy drinking, was expecting more for the $20 pricetag.
